original_question: My friend says everyone does it so it must be okay. Is that a good reason?

lesson.subject: philosophy_core
lesson.title: Logic Seeds: Reasons and Conclusions
lesson.description: An early logic lane that helps you notice the difference between what you think and why you think it, and shows why some reasons are weak.

content.spine_position: Kâ??8 seed for all later logic. Begins as noticing 'I think' vs 'I think... because', becomes informal logic and fallacies in high school, and formal logic in university (propositional/predicate), with advanced logics at graduate level.
prepares_for: Political philosophy (reasons about justice and power).
Law, debate, media literacy, and scientific reasoning.
kid_core_explanations: An argument is not a fight. It is when someone tells you what they think and gives a reason.
A conclusion is what someone wants you to believe. A reason is why they say it.
Sometimes people say things that sound strong but are not real reasons, like calling names or just saying 'everyone does it'.
key_concepts: This is what I think vs this is why I think it.
Conclusion (what you want someone to believe).
Reason (why you say the conclusion is true).
Name-calling instead of reasons (attacking the person).
'Everyone does it' as a weak reason (popularity, not proof).
'Because I said so' as an appeal to authority without support.

micro_activities.name: spot_reason_vs_conclusion
micro_activities.prompt: Listen: 'You should wear a helmet because it keeps your head safe.' Which part is the reason? Which part is the conclusion?
micro_activities.expected_pattern: Reason: 'it keeps your head safe'. Conclusion: 'you should wear a helmet'.

micro_activities.name: is_that_a_reason_name_calling
micro_activities.prompt: Your friend says: 'Youâ??re stupid if you donâ??t like my favorite game.' Is that a reason for thinking the game is good, or just name-calling?
micro_activities.expected_pattern: This is name-calling, not a real reason.

micro_activities.name: everyone_does_it
micro_activities.prompt: Someone says: 'Everyone in my class cheats, so itâ??s okay.' Does 'everyone does it' really show it is okay, or is that a weak reason?
micro_activities.expected_pattern: It is a weak reason: many people doing something does not make it right.

guided_questions: Can you tell me something you believe, and one reason you have for it?
Think of a time someone tried to convince you of something. What did they say as a reason?
When someone calls names instead of giving reasons, how does that feel? Does it help you understand?

silent_questions: What (if anything) are they treating as a reason?
Is this more like 'I feel' or 'I think... because...'?
pattern_labels: Attacking the person vs giving a reason.
'Everyone does it' as popularity, not proof.
'Because I said so' as unsupported authority.

moves: Ask the child first before explaining.
Reflect their answer back in slightly clearer language.
Offer gentle corrections ('Good catch...', 'One more thing to notice is...').
Start with either/or questions ('reason or conclusion?') before asking 'why?'.
templates: Try this: 'I think ___ because ___'. Can you fill it in with your own belief and reason?

reflection_prompts: Today, notice one time when someone gives a conclusion without a reason. How did that feel?
Try saying one of your beliefs to someone else using 'I think ___ because ___'. How did it change the conversation?
content.next_suggestion: Next, you can explore simple ideas about fairness and kindness in everyday stories, and practice giving reasons for why something feels fair or unfair.

practice.prompt: Can you tell me something you believe, and one reason you have for it? You can start with: 'I think ___ because ___.'
practice.child_answer: My friend says everyone does it so it must be okay. Is that a good reason?
practice.prime_paraphrase: You said: My friend says everyone does it so it must be okay. Is that a good reason?
practice.prime_feedback: Thank you for sharing that. You are practicing the habit of saying both what you think and why you think it. That is the first step in clear thinking.
practice.follow_up_question: If you wanted to change your mind about this belief, what kind of reason would you need to hear?
